Award.AwardTitle: Complex Evolutionary Genetics of Gonadal Differentiation in a Classic Model of Behavior, Astatotilapia burtoni
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proper gonadal differentiation is absolutely fundamental to the fitness of sexually reproducing species, yet surprising diversity exists among species in the mechanisms that determines males vs. females. Genetic sex determination is one common mechanism, yet little is known about how novel sex determination genes arise, interact, and evolve in populations. Historically, genetic sex determination research has largely focused on a handful of single-factor, chromosomal sex determination systems. More recently, genetic sex determination has been mapped in a broader set of species, revealing a diverse catalog of sex determination genes in a variety of chromosomal contexts. Polygenic sex determination (PSD) has also been confirmed in multiple taxa, where multiple genetic factors direct sexual development. PSD challenges traditional thinking regarding genetic sex determination systems, while providing powerful strategies to explore the evolution and development of sex determination, including comparisons of siblings with multiple genetic modes of sex determination. In other words, while individuals of species with PSD develop as male or female, several genetic types of males and females may exist. The cichlid fish species Astatotilapia burtoni uses PSD to determine male vs. female development, providing a model to understand the evolution and development of genetic sex determination. This work aims to provide the most comprehensive analysis of a PSD system to date, using A. burtoni as a model system. The project should reveal novel genes and gene networks driving gonadal differentiation and development, while yielding important evolutionary insights. The research will also produce important genome resources for A. burtoni, a model for neural and behavioral biology. Undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will carry out proposed experiments, preparing them for careers in science. Additionally, K-12 teachers will be given direct research experience through co-mentoring by the researchers and the Kenan Fellows Program, together developing educational materials broadly scaled for state classrooms, regional public outreach venues, and the world wide web.

Multiple sex determination loci segregate in A. burtoni, producing many genotypic sexes and the opportunity to study the interaction of multiple sex determination genes within individuals. The proposed research uses an integrated approach involving genetic mapping, genome assembly and annotation of sex chromosomes, comparative genomics, and gene network analysis during gonadal differentiation. Aims include mapping and functional testing of multiple novel sex determination genes, and tracing the evolutionary impact of novel sex determination alleles on the structure of chromosomes where they reside, including functional evolution of linked genes. Gene expression analyses through sexual development will supplement these mapping and annotation efforts, and provide understanding of how multiple genetic sex switches are integrated during development. Gene expression analyses among different genetic sexes during development will also reveal core genetic networks underlying gonadal development, and yield insight into how genetic networks evolve without negatively impacting indispensable complex traits. Since A. burtoni is a longstanding behavior model, it provides excellent context for analysis of secondary sexual characteristics, including existing behavioral gene expression data, in relation to the various modes of sex determination present in the species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes report

Proper development of the early gonad into functional female (ovary) or male (testis) organs is essential to the reproductive fitness of a species, yet the initial signals that determine male and female trajectories vary widely across species, and include both environmental and genetic triggers. Relatively little is known about how novel sex determination switches arise, interact, and evolve in populations to produce the diversity we see across species today. Additionally, when new genetic sex determination genes arise in the genome, they can impact the evolution of the chromosomes on which they arise, yet this process is poorly understood.

Here, we use the cichlid fish species Astatotilapia burtoni as a model system to understand the evolution of genetic sex determination systems and early stages of sex chromosome evolution, using genetic mapping and genomic techniques. We characterize a polygenic sex determination system in A. burtoni, involving the interaction of two, independently segregating sex chromosomes. We mapped an XY sex determination system to chromosome 5, and identified a distinct fusion of chromosomes 5 and 14 in A. burtoni, relative to other cichlid species. We also identified a ZW sex determination locus on chromosome 13. With genetics markers to track these chromosomes, we were able to reveal how they interact to ultimately initiate male versus female development – the male-determining Y allele on chromosome 5-14 epistatically dominates the female-determining W allele on chromosome 13, so that individuals inheriting both Y and W alleles develop as males.

We further investigated the evolution of the two sex determination loci with an integrated approach, using high-throughput sequencing of genomes (to analyze genetic variation), transcriptomes (variation in gene expression), and epigenomes (regulation of gene expression). By comparing the genome sequence of individuals with different sex determination genotypes, we were able to identify and refine the genetic intervals containing the sex determination genes. For both sex determination systems the intervals are relatively small (several million bases each) demonstrating that the sex chromosomes are homomorphic in A. burtoni and may represent early sex stages of sex chromosome evolution. The two genetic intervals do not contain any genes previously implicated as sex determination genes, suggesting that A. burtoni uses previously unknown genetic switches for sex determination. Nevertheless, our analysis of genome-wide gene expression patterns during early gonad differentiation indicates that at the level of gene expression, common genetic pathways of vertebrate gonadal differentiation are activated consistent with male versus female development. Through our analysis we have also worked to improve the relatively fragmented A. burtoni genome assembly to provide a solid reference for analyses. We have improved the local continuity of the assembly at the two sex loci, and are working to improve the assembly genome-wide.

Broader Impacts

The project will provide genomic resources to the scientific community for comparative genomic analyses and genetic sex determination research. The species A. burtoni is most commonly used as a model in research exploring sexual differentiation and sex-specific physiology and behavior. Thus, our findings demonstrating a complex genetic basis of sex determination provide important context for on-going research in several labs.

The work provided extensive training, including support for two post-doctoral trainees and one Genetics PhD student. One of the post-doctoral trainees identifies as part of an underrepresented minority group, and she successfully obtained a tenure-track faculty position during her tenure on the project. The project also supported undergraduate training in two ways. First, seven undergraduate students performed independent research projects related to the project, with two undergraduates included as co-authors on publications, and the others to be included on pending publications. Fourteen additional undergraduates received hands-on research training as part of a formal course developed by the PI and the PhD student supported by the project; this course was highly successful and continues to be offered. All twenty undergraduates presented their research at symposia or conferences. Three high school teachers were also trained under the project in mentored summer research projects. Lab members helped the teachers develop curriculum related to the projects, and visited teachers’ classroom and took part in student projects. Throughout the project, lab members engaged the public through local outreach projects at the NC Museum of Natural Sciences and other venues. Two interactive exhibits featuring A. burtoni research, “Fish Face Frenzy!” and “Dances with Fishes”, were each carried out at least annually at the museum, the largest regional venue for public science outreach and education.
